segments.text: We're talking with Mr. William South, and he was telling us about this portrait.
It's a painting of John Barrymore as Hamlet.
It was done by Decker, who was a great pal of Barrymore's.
And at home, the first time I saw it was in Barrymore's home on Tower Road, which Katherine Hepburn was leasing.
And my wife and I housed it for six weeks.
Oh, this was Peggy.
When did we house sit for Hepburn?
What?
When did we house sit for Hepburn?
Eddie was four.
Four, so that's 45 years ago.
And I admired that painting, and then we became very good friends with Kate and Spence, and actually Spence's family, too.
And the last time I saw him alive, I guess I stopped and looked at that painting, and he said to the rapper, why don't we give that painting to Bill?
He likes it.
And she said, well, let me think about that.
And eventually, cut through a long story, we were having lunch with her in London,
And she said, do you see what they're painting?
And I said, yes.
She said, well, go.
I'll tell my housekeeper you're coming over and get it.
So that's the ship up there.
Got an association.
Was a ship that Kate gave to Spencer.
And after his death, she invited Kate to me over and said, if you'd like something out of this room of Spencer's, take your pick.
And I said, well, I'd like that ship.
And she said, well, I gave that to Spencer.
So she said, I'm very fond of it.
You may have it.
That was Spencer Tracy's ship.
Yeah, yeah.
Set on his mantle.
These are.
But a lot of these, before we start the real thing, we're friends of the Wright brothers' family.
And this is a part of the original airplane, the first airplane to fly.
As he says, these parts were broken while the plane was on the ground, overturned by wind after the fourth flight of that day, December 17, 1903.
And this is Wolverine.
Wilbur carried that all over the world.
Orville Reddell parted with it, even after Wilbur's death.
And the family considered it one of the few things of Wilbur that they retained.
And anyway, this incident was an interesting little item.
The first edition, volume one, of the West Side News, publisher Orville Wright.
I'm getting this.
But here's the satchel and Wilbur at Kitty Hawk.
There it is.
And then there's a photographer.
Now, where did you find the photo?
I got that from the family.
And another thing in here is Tyrone.
Oh, this is the boy.
Here's a cartoon that appeared, I think, in the New York Daily News or something.
Coming back from Europe, being welcomed by Wilbur Hedges.
As he says, the satchel card.
The satchel, they said, went every place to all.
Now, was that a personal thing or tools?
Or what are you supposed to find in it?
He carried his socks in there.
So anyway, where I've been at Wright, Miller, who's now 93 or 94, and her husband, also about that age, are good friends of ours, and we were pleased they had.
That's quite an extraordinary event, isn't it?
They had some of the propellers.
Uh-huh.
You know, and they're living them, and then they eventually gave that— They gave it to the Air Museum, and they permitted them a $750,000 write-off for that propeller.
These people lived modestly.
Mm-hmm.
And still gave all these wonderful historical things that were worth, you know.
I think the family sold the Kitty Hawk to the Smithsonian for one dollar.
They have a whole album of checks for one dollar.
Where they sold things to the museum to give, basically given it.
Do they live in Ohio?
Yes, they still live in Dayton.
We talked to them quite a lot.

any okay because it was a major major i'm going to put this close to you over here because what i have to say is when i was doing some research in the newbury last uh last fall i was going through some things and you actually have been a couple of times on a tamalei but we've been on the the one that that
University of Schroderbach, the Regenstein.
That's exactly right.
I was the underbidder on that.
What happened was that I... I had made a deal with Lou Feldman to bid for me, and Lou and I had falling out just before the sale because we found somebody else.
He found somebody else to bid on me, and I said, let me do that.
He said, no.
It's not.
And I said, well, in that case, we bought company because I'm going to bid on my own.
And he said, fine.
So I bid on my own, did not think the thoughts of John Fleming about it, who I've used before, and I knew.
John later said to me, I wish you'd have talked to me, Bill, because he said, I could have saved you a lot of trouble.
He said, you couldn't buy that book for any amount of money.
Mrs. Regenstein had said, buy it, John, just buy it.
So I stopped at $120,000, which was far the most
Well, you've got to fit on the board.
They sold for $123,000.
And then I thought, well, that's the end of my efforts to get Tamerlane, and then this other copy came on the market.
And I actually had earmarked four core items that I would love to have had.
One was Tamerlane, which I did not expect again.
At that sale.
At that sale.
And then I felt if I didn't get Tamerlane, I would then secondly try to buy our wrap.
That would be a very interesting item.
Yeah, excuse me.
I'd love to have it if I don't have it.
And if I didn't get Al Rapp, I was going to bid on the tail in the original rappers.
I have the raven in the rap, but I didn't have the tail.
And if I didn't get that, I was going to bid on the 1831 poems.
But if I got Panelline, I wasn't going to bid on anything because I didn't have any money left.
So that's actually what happened.
So you went to New York with a budget then?
Yeah, which I promptly exceeded.
No, we talked about it.
Peggy's been very supportive in all this, and I said, we're going to spend a lot of money on one book, and I don't know whether it's going to be Al Arab or Paralene or the poems, and she said, fine.
I don't think I would have gone any higher than I did on Paralene, because it was a major stretch for us, and
Secondly, I had some other things I would have settled for.
Is that all you got at that sale, by the way?
Yes, that's all I've been on.
One, it was the talk of the hall, really, because not many people knew who you were right there.
And this elegant gentleman and his wife, you were with him, as I recollect, were there, and they fit on one item, and that was that.
Well, a true story that you might find interesting enough to put in your book.
On the previous family, there's a head of the Red Book Department of Courage was a man named Arthur Freeman.
Arthur came over to that sale.
What sale was it?
This was the gardens.
No, that was just a manuscript, a book and manuscript sale.
This was the one that the guy found up in New Hampshire.
No.
The one prior to that.
This was the one prior to that.
This was part of a major collector's work.
Anyway, at that sale... We're doing good.
Go ahead.
We're doing fine.
Arthur Freeman came over representing Quaritches, and he and I knew each other very little bit.
We know each other better now.
And he was at a time when he told me Quaritches didn't have much money to acquire things, and they had put a very tight leash on him, and they said, don't spend too much money.
And he said, okay.
So he came to the sale, and after...
Tamerlane sold.
He wired his boss back in London.
Highlight of the sale, Tamerlane.
Sale price $123,000.
Self underbidder.
And they thought he was the underbidder.
And so they called him up and said, we told you not to bid.
That's a great story.
Well, that's the taste of it.
And the doctor said it's a good story for him.
I guess I asked you about the Tamerlane, not only when it started our talk, because that's how I met you, but perhaps you could use that as a window into your thinking as a collector.
Why were you so set on the Tamerlane?
And maybe that will give me a little insight on your focus as a collector.
It is obviously the high spot of American literature, in my opinion it is.
It's called The Black Tulip, as you know.
And I guess an ego thing gets into your equation when you start going after a book like that.
And I had a decent Poe collection.
Peggy bought me, I think.
The first Poe item was Arthur Gordon Pym.
Arthur Gordon Pym.
Arthur Gordon Pym.
Yeah, and that got me going on Poe.
And then over the years, we bought Murders in the Room, more of a George sale, which was a very rare item.
And then I eventually bought The Raven in wrappers.
And I have acquired some manuscript material.
I have a fair copy of his poem for Annie, Thank Heaven the Name of the Crisis of the Last, which Peggy kind of forced me to buy it, because she kept saying, buy it.
And I said, well, I don't know.
It's a lot of money.
Anyway, so I had built up what I thought was a decent book collection.
But I was minus the two or three really high phosphates from Al Raft and, of course, family.
So having lost it the other time, and at that time, too, we said if we buy this book, we've got to sell one of the children because, you know, it was a lot of money.
And this time we decided, you know, in my lifetime, I may never give another crack at it.
I think there's only two, maybe three in private hands.
I guess there's three in private hands.
You know that Dick Manning's books are being sold this fall.
Have you read that?
No, I didn't know that, no.
I'd be happy to tell you a little bit about that.
That's a very interesting story, including his tablet.
All of his books had a little problem, I guess.
It's one of the Shakespeare's that he bought.
I know, he bought those recently.
In November of 89 at the garden sale.
So there will be another... Another Tamerlane.
Another Tamerlane.
And Bart Auerbach, by the way, says to say hello to you.
Oh, yeah, nice fan.
Nice fan.
He has very nice things about you.
He thinks that your Tamerlane, by the way, is better than Maddie's.
I think it probably is.
From what I hear, I never saw his.
The one we did not get at the University of Florida is the best copy I've ever seen.
It was a superior copy.
And it's very funny because right after the University of Chicago bought that, we went to the University of Chicago.
Peggy and I both went to the University of Chicago.
And right after they got a letter soliciting funds for their rare book department, just talking to their own fellow, they'd expect me to give money to outfib myself.
That's great.
That's great.
Well, anyway, I didn't make a contribution.
But we were very friendly with Bob Norsenthal, who was there, and Bob was there.
Nice man.
Nice man.
Just before I got out there.
Nice man.
He was very helpful to me in an item we were very proud of.
We have part of Emily Bronte and Anne Bronte's diary.
And the way that came about was that Bill Cagle, do you know him of the Lilly Library?
Lilly went to see him.
Well, Bill Cagle called me one day and said, I know where Emily and part of Emily and Anne's diary is.
We can't afford it or it doesn't fit in with our collection.
And he said, I thought of you.
And he said, I'll put you in touch with the lady who has it.
He said, I don't think she'll sell it to you, but I'll tell you who has it.
He told me a lady in Chicago named Frances Cooper had it.
And Frances was a wonderful old lady.
She was certainly in her 80s, don't you think, when we met her.
And she'd made her money with the Wrigley account.
I understand that this lady personally handled the Wrigley account for years and years.
And she had a wonderful Virginia Woolf collector.
And she didn't really much care about the Brantes, or said so.
And she had this diary, and the first thing she said to me when I walked in the door, I went to see her the first time by myself, and Peggy went later times.
She said, I'm not going to say The Brownie Diary.
And I said, fine, but I'm really just thrilled to see it, but she felt a little happy to show it to you.
So we kept up, this went on for at least three or four years, and I was thinking every time we went there, she'd say, well, I'm not going to stop there.
I said, no, I know you're not.
I'm not asking you to.
And then once when we went there, we were her house guests.
She had lost.
We could not find it.
And she gave us carte blanche.
Well, she had nieces, and we were the house guests, and I'm proud to collect it.
You know, the scene is set for a crime.
And she let us go through the whole house.
We could not find it for her.
And then I heard that she passed on.
And I contacted the nieces, and they said they had found it just before she died in the hospital.
She remembered where she put it.
And they knew that she wanted me to have it.
And they had gave it to Bob Rosenthal to appraise.
And Bob Rosenthal felt unsure of himself in making the appraisal.
So he involved John Fleming in New York.
And the two of them appraised the book and told me what it was appraised.
That meant I bought it.
So we had a nice... What happened to the rest of her...
So the ginger wolf she gave to her university, didn't she?
Was it Smith or something like that?
I think it was Smith.
She gave a lot to Northwestern.
She gave to, in general, she gave away.
Were these things that she had acquired?
Yes.
She said she had never hoped anything she had.
She was either given away or kept.
So at some point that she had acquired a diary and then kind of lost interest in it.
You know, I don't think she really did.
In my opinion, she really loved it.
And it was a little game we were kind of playing.
She knew that I wanted it.
She wasn't about to sell it.
She didn't need the money.
And I think she was very pleased to have it.
The Grantees, every four years, they wrote a couple of pages on their birthday.
And this was one of the first things that it's coming.
transcripts of the diary that started 30 years old.
My collecting, if you want that background, started with our daughter.
Our daughter is now a middle-aged lady with two teenage daughters, but once she graduated from high school, we asked her what she wanted for high school graduation.
Is that accurate?
It was junior high.
Junior high, okay.
She was quite young.
You were living out here?
Yes, we were around here.
We've lived out here for forty-five years, forty-six years, forty-seven years.
Anyway, she said that she'd seen a huge copy, she thought it was the first edition, as it turned out to be, of Huckleberry Pink.
And it was in a huge bookstore, and it was $50.
And that's what she wanted.
So we bought it for her, and she was very pleased, and it was on that library shelf up there.
That's an unusual thing for a... Yes.
Well, she's now a professional librarian.
She doesn't work at it because she's raising her children, but that's her master's degree in library science.
So it's been ingrained for a long time.
And then we all went to London, by all I mean my daughter and Peggy and I. And she wanted to go get something in Dickens.
So we went to shops we'd heard about, Spencer's, specialized in Dickens.
And I think she had a hundred dollars to spend.
Well, she had a little more than that.
She had her life saving, and I think it was around three hundred.
Three hundred dollars.
Yeah.
She wanted, Dickens was her.
Really?
It was a big thing.
What's this daughter's name?
Barbara.
Barbara.
That's my daughter's name.
Barbara Lloyd Malone.
Yeah, so she, well, what happened, Bill had to come back.
Barbara and I went to W.G.
Spencer.
And we went first to the Dickens house.
and she asked them where she should go, and they told her it doesn't have the expenses.

She also asked them, by this time she had just graduated from high school, she asked if she could have some of the red geraniums to take over to his grave, because we were going from the Dickens House to Westminster Abbey, and there were some elderly ladies kind of taking care of the Dickens House.
They were told to wrote it.
They said the scarlet geranium was his favorite flower, and that's why they were in the box.
So we went from there and took the little bouquet from his house to his grave at Westminster Abbey.
And then the next day we went and made out for him.
She made it at W.P.
Spencer.
So when we got there, Nellie Clark was the lady's name.
She said, how much do you have to spare?
Barbara told her, and she said, well, you must have an autograph.
And she said, she put out a few things, because when Barbara called, she told her what she was interested in.
So she bought a straightforward edition of Tale of Two Setties, wasn't it?
Pickwick.
Pickwick.
And a check.
And the Pickwick had a photograph, kind of tipped in of Dickens, and his
sisters or daughters, I always forget which.
And with that, we then came home.
The following year, Bill and I went to London, and he said, you know, I'd kind of like to go to that rare bookstore last year.
So he called this clerk, and he said, my daughter and wife were in last year.
Oh, she said, I remember she got a straightforward edition of Pickwick and the check.
You know, she knew exactly.
So, that was the beginning.
Were you feeling the onset of the virus?
Yeah, I did.
And I've always been a collector, but not a book.
I mean, I've got a magic collection.
I've got part of the Hurston Show upstairs.
I'm a collector of Antioch.
I'm a Russell Bill collector.
I am an early Hollywood collector.
I've got more Valentino stuff than you've ever seen in your life.
I've got thousands of pictures of Valentino.
We live in a bubble.
Well, I wanted to be a collector, but I did not know anything about it.
Oh, we were meaning from childhood?
Yeah, I think so, really.
And then, I kid about this a little bit, but there's some truth to it.
I started looking for books for Barbara, and some of them were fairly expensive.
And after I bought them, I thought, well, we really can't give Barbara this expensive gift for no reason.
We've got to be fair to our other sons.
And so I started seeing
And I said, I've done a terrific library.
Barbara's still waiting for her next book.
But really, Barbara did get me going, and then I got very interested.
And I, too, got interested first in Dickens.
Dickens was my first collector.
And I think you indicated on the phone that he's probably your greatest single collector.
Well, it is.
That whole shelf over there, those three panels, they're all Dickens, first editions.
I have 23 or 24 presentation chapters.
Hans Christian Andersen and George Eliot.
Is there one of those here that we can see?
Yeah, they're both here.
I brought one of the Hans Christian Andersen.
What did you describe to Hans Christian Andersen?
One to George Eliot.
Those are, when we say association copies, those are association copies.
I have one of the, it is known that Dickens autographed X number of bodies, I've forgotten exactly how many, of The Christmas Carol on, I think, the 17th of December.
That's the earliest known date that he inscribed a copy, and I have one of those.
So I have some nice associations.
We have to tell you anything that you'd like.
Yeah, we'll tell you.
If you have any particular interest.
I think at some point, I'd love to get just a little more of a background.
Well, you know, Peggy is, in a modest way, collected Robert Louis-Stevenson, particularly child-striving verses.
It gave us a mutual interest when we'd travel.
You know, we'd look up bookstores.
Instead of going to a saloon, we'd go to a bookstore.
So it worked out very well.
That's the first thing we do.
We went out to the Huntington this morning, and Bill Moffat, we were there to see Bill, and they had a book sale going on over there.
He said, you're not buying books.
I'm sorry.
We come to California area.
I have a sense that you're a collector.
I mean,
Clearly, this has to be a synergistic kind of thing almost, don't you?
Well, I'm not really a collector.
Apparently, I'm an exception to the rule that they're not always sympathetic to the husband's collection.
But I have enjoyed being on the fringe.
I really don't have much interest in acquiring.
I enjoy the project probably more than it.
How do you mean I enjoy being on the fringe?
If you could just elaborate on that.
Being on the fringe of the collecting?
The fringe, meaning that on the fringe of Bill's collecting.
I'm exposed to it, I'm part of it, but I'm not the one now.
It is true that Bill will hesitate to buy
And I encouraged him to go ahead and do it.
He had said, we often regret what we don't bought.
You seldom regret what you bought.
You say, gee whiz, I should have done this.
But I don't have the interest in acquiring myself.
If there is a sale, to give you an example, if there's a sale coming up, I think you won't even look at the catalog.
No, I don't.
I will look at the catalog, and I will say to her, hey, there's a Bronte letter, or there's a Poe item.
I'd love to have it.
She says, what is it?
We talk about it.
If we go to the sale and bid on it, she's there saying, keep going.
Oh, they're frightening, aren't they?
You see, when he bid on the first Tamra line, the one that went to the University of Chicago,
I was so incensed, as was Bill, at this deal, for being so, you know, crooked.
There's no other way to put it.
Well, he was opportunistic.
Opportunistic and unprofessional.
Now, honestly, at that point in our lives, we would have had to put a mortgage on the house to buy that book, had Bill gotten it for $120,000.
Would you have done that?
Well, we had assets.
We could have done it, but it wasn't a case of... I mean, but did it mean enough to you that you would consider that?
Yeah, yeah.
I wasn't prepared to do it.
I did it.
You know, the proof is that I did it.
Yeah, and I was in full agreement.
So tell me, Phil, why would you consider... You didn't, I understand you didn't, but what is so important about getting this item that you would even consider
Well, I mean, certainly it's not because of the value of it.
I know it's an investment.
No, I don't.
We don't buy for investment.
It's rarity, I think.
It's rarity.
It was the... He thought it would be the last one he would ever have an opportunity to buy.
I don't think that you can say you have a great Poe collection if you haven't got talent.
You can say you've got a good Poe collection.
I don't think you can say you've got a great Lewis Carroll collection if you haven't got a 65-hour.
You see, it's not like going and buying a mint coat or something.
It is something of intrinsic value that will hold it to value, probably increase in value.
So whether you are putting your money in one place or another... Yeah, I'm going to clarify.
In fact, undoubtedly increase in value.
But to clarify a point that's obvious, I think, really, is we weren't going to have to deny our children going to college,
we weren't going to have to, you know, take my mother's off of the lounge or something.
You know, it wasn't that kind of thing.
It was just that $120,000 cash would, you know, have to sell them.
Well, how many of us have the bouncing or welder?
You know, and it's obvious that you could afford to do it, but I'm looking for the, you know, the mindset.
Now, we did.
Connie and I interviewed a guy in Sacramento last year on our last trip.
who in fact mortgaged his house to get a Hemingway item.
And when we were there, his wife was in the process of divorcing.
No, I don't think we've ever done that.
I think that we have spent more on some books than we planned to, but never, I don't think, at the expense of security or comfort.
I remember when we bought our 65 Alice,
Peggy was, she didn't mind it, the book collected.
Peggy wanted to give me, was it a birthday present?
I think it was.
She wanted to give me a birthday present.
And what she now says she had in mind was maybe a $500 book.
Or a thousand, you know, something like that.
And we have had very good luck with a dealer in Chicago at that time, Hamlin Barker.
The books are now dead, but there's someone who's taken over there.
But Hamlin Barker were wonderful old ladies,
always had something kind of special.
And I called them, long distance, and I said to Miss Hamill, I'll tell you what you want to buy me, she knew both of us, and buy me this present, and what have you got?
And she said, oh dear, which was one of her favorite expressions when she had something special.
She said, oh dear, I've got something coming in.
People don't know we're going to get it.
It may be beyond what you plan to spend.
I said, what is it?
She said, Alice, 65 hours.
And I said, well, forgive me, Francis, but, you know, I know the consensus.
I know where they all are.
There isn't one for sale that I know of.
She said, well, yes, Bill, there is.
She said, the Forsheimer Library, the son, once in a while, takes to buy a mountain and sell it.
And he has, a few years ago, sold this to another lady.
And she now wants to dispose of it.
She asked us to do so.
And she also has two, three others.
And I said, well, what do you want for it?
She said, $25,000.
That's a steal, though.
I know.
I'm not even thinking $500 or $1,000.
I have to hang up the phone and say, well, she catches me.
Now, she had quoted me two, three other things.
She had a...
A Russian translation, that was $1,000.
She had a beautiful copy, I bought it finally, but of the 66 Alice, the finest copy I've ever seen.
That was another $2,000.
The significance of the 65, that's the one he wanted to suppress, isn't it?
Yes, yes.
There are 19 copies, I think.
There are, I think, two or three in private hand.
Justin Schiller has one.
Anyway, I said she's got a 65,000.
I want to hear about it in this poem.
20 years ago?
I don't know.
Approximately.
It's in the 60s, 70s.
But he thought he was trying to deal.
So he did talk to me and couldn't call him a pack.
And he said, you know, I think I'll offer $25,000 for all of them.
They're waiting to get him through for me, $1,000 worth, along with the $65.
So he called her back.
She said, oh, dear.
She said, you know, we have someone waiting now who will pay the $25,000.
So he snapped it up.
But we didn't snap it up in the sense of, sure, we'll do it.
We really did some soul-searching about whether we... At that time, it was the most we ever spent for any book.
And the reason we bought it was the same reason I guess we bought Camino.
We felt we would never again get another chance, I thought, in my lifetime probably.
But it turned out there was another one that came up, two of us, in one sale.
It was Heritage, wasn't it?
It closed you?
I was just going to say, you know, the rule of thumb now is anything
10 or 15 years ago, you can add a zero in the value.
I was offered a $300,000.
Yeah, Mark Heim called me and said, yes, we had a client.
That's fine, and that's not likely to be the kind of detail.
The funny part, my sister was visiting at the time that Mark Heim made the offer, and she lives in Mount Floyd, but much in Washington.
So she was privy to the conversation with the law discussion, so she called her son and told him about this offer.
And then she said, and he didn't take it.
That's why.
I'll just use it without mentioning the individual.
Yes, that's my fault.
You mentioned Luke Bowman.
Did you know him well?
Well, he bid for me two or three different sales.
I did get mad at him, as I mentioned earlier, when he accepted a bid higher than mine.
The thing that made it so bad, I won't bore you with all the details.
No, this is enough movies.
Kelvin's an individual I'm interested in.
Well, the thing that upset us the most was we had dinner with Luke Kelvin the night before that sale with Tamerlane.
And I had given Luke some other bids.
And he said, what are you going to do about Tamerlane?
And I said, I'm not going to bid on it.
He said, why not?
And I said, because it's going to go for too much money.
He said, how do you know that?
And I said, well, what do you think it'll go for?
He said, I know exactly what it'll go for.
He said, it'll go for $50,000.
I said, why do you know that?
He said, well, because the guy that bought it, Stockhausen, I guess it was.
Stockhausen bought it.
I think he paid $40,000 for it.
He said, it was very recently.
He said, the universities don't have the money to bid.
I believe they've got a $45,000 reserve on it, and I think the first bid over that will get it.
So you buy it for $50,000.
without going into a lot of detail.
We said, okay, if it goes for that, we'll give up.
He said, fine.
So I arrived at the sale the next morning.
All excited.
